response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "The purpose of this Act is to establish a reduction in the general excise tax rate on gross proceeds or income from the sale of groceries that are eligible for purchase under the supplemental nutrition assistance program or special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children and from the sale of nonprescription drugs. [CHUNK_9] This bill reduces the general excise tax rate on the gross proceeds or income from the sale of such groceries, regardless of the means of purchase and the program eligibility of the purchaser. [CHUNK_25] It also requires the department of business, economic development and tourism to conduct an economic cost-benefit analysis on the general excise reductions and submit a report to the legislature. [CHUNK_10]",
  "appropriations": "The provided legislative documents do not specify any appropriations for this measure. [CHUNK_0] No funding amounts for staffing, training, or other operational costs are detailed in the bill. [CHUNK_0] Therefore, there are no specific appropriations to report. [CHUNK_0]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The bill's premise is based on the finding that the cost of living in Hawaii is extremely high. [CHUNK_1] It references a United States Department of Agriculture statistic that a Hawaii family on a thrifty food plan spends $1,794.60 (HB933_.HTM.txt) per month on food. [CHUNK_5] Based on this, the bill assumes this family would pay over $800 (HB933_.HTM.txt) a year in state taxes on those groceries. [CHUNK_5]",
  "agency_impact": "The department of business, economic development, and tourism is required to conduct an economic cost-benefit analysis on the general excise tax reductions for calendar year 2026. [CHUNK_22] This department shall submit a report of its findings from the analysis, including any recommendations and proposed legislation, to the legislature before the regular session of 2027. [CHUNK_23] The Department of Taxation will be impacted by the need to implement and administer a new reduced tax rate for specific goods. [CHUNK_11]",
  "economic_impact": "Lowering the tax rate on groceries and nonprescription drugs will have an immediate positive impact on Hawaii's cost of living by lowering the cost of these necessary items. [CHUNK_8] The legislature finds that taxing the sale of groceries is generally considered regressive and disproportionately hurts working families because they spend a higher percentage of their income on food. [CHUNK_3] A 2021 study by the University of Hawaii at Manoa stated that forty-eight per cent of Hawaii families with children are experiencing food insecurity. [CHUNK_2]",
  "policy_impact": "This Act amends Chapter 237, Hawaii Revised Statutes, by adding two new sections to establish a reduced general excise tax rate for eligible groceries and nonprescription drugs. [CHUNK_10] The tax rate will be one-half per cent less than the rate that would have applied pursuant to section 237-13. [CHUNK_12] This policy recognizes that certain items should have a lower tax burden, similar to the existing general exemption for amounts received by certain entities for selling prescription drugs. [CHUNK_7]",
  "revenue_sources": "The bill does not identify any new revenue sources to support the program or offset the tax reduction. [CHUNK_0] The reduction in the general excise tax will result in a decrease in revenue for the State's general fund. [CHUNK_8] No grants, fees, or other revenue streams are mentioned in the provided text. [CHUNK_0]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "Beginning January 1, 2026, the State will collect a tax equivalent to one-half per cent less than the standard rate on the sale of eligible groceries. [CHUNK_11] A tax equivalent to one-half per cent less than the standard rate will also be collected on the sale of nonprescription drugs, also beginning January 1, 2026. [CHUNK_17] This will result in a recurring loss of general fund revenue for the foreseeable future. [CHUNK_11] The exact fiscal impact is undetermined, but the bill provides an example from the United States Department of Agriculture, where a Hawaii family on a thrifty food plan spends $1,794.60 (HB933_.HTM.txt) per month on food. [CHUNK_5] This family would pay over $800 (HB933_.HTM.txt) a year in state taxes on those groceries, indicating the potential scale of the tax reduction's impact on an individual basis. [CHUNK_5] Even with the refundable food/excise tax credit, a family would likely get back less than one-half of those state taxes paid on groceries. [CHUNK_6] The department of business, economic development, and tourism is required to conduct an economic cost-benefit analysis on the general excise tax reductions for calendar year 2026. [CHUNK_22] A report with findings and recommendations is to be submitted to the legislature prior to the convening of the regular session of 2027. [CHUNK_23] This report should provide a clearer picture of the long-term fiscal implications. [CHUNK_23] The Act itself is scheduled to take effect on July 1, 2025. [CHUNK_24]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "This measure will reduce the State's operating revenue. [CHUNK_8] Beginning January 1, 2026, there shall be assessed and collected a tax equivalent to one-half per cent less than the rate that would have applied on the gross proceeds from the sale of eligible groceries and nonprescription drugs. [CHUNK_11] This reduction in the general excise tax rate will decrease tax collections from these sales. [CHUNK_25]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The provided legislative documents do not mention any capital expenditures. [CHUNK_0] There are no anticipated investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure associated with this measure. [CHUNK_0] Therefore, there is no expected capital expenditure impact. [CHUNK_0]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The fiscal implications are expected to be ongoing as the bill does not include a sunset clause for the tax reduction. [CHUNK_11] The reduced tax rate on eligible groceries and nonprescription drugs will continue indefinitely, resulting in a permanent reduction of general fund revenues. [CHUNK_17] The long-term fiscal impact will depend on the volume of sales of these specific goods in the state. [CHUNK_12]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "No previous fiscal note was provided for comparison. [CHUNK_0]"
}

parts.text:
{
  "overview": "The purpose of this Act is to establish a reduction in the general excise tax rate on gross proceeds or income from the sale of groceries that are eligible for purchase under the supplemental nutrition assistance program or special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children and from the sale of nonprescription drugs. [CHUNK_9] This bill reduces the general excise tax rate on the gross proceeds or income from the sale of such groceries, regardless of the means of purchase and the program eligibility of the purchaser. [CHUNK_25] It also requires the department of business, economic development and tourism to conduct an economic cost-benefit analysis on the general excise reductions and submit a report to the legislature. [CHUNK_10]",
  "appropriations": "The provided legislative documents do not specify any appropriations for this measure. [CHUNK_0] No funding amounts for staffing, training, or other operational costs are detailed in the bill. [CHUNK_0] Therefore, there are no specific appropriations to report. [CHUNK_0]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The bill's premise is based on the finding that the cost of living in Hawaii is extremely high. [CHUNK_1] It references a United States Department of Agriculture statistic that a Hawaii family on a thrifty food plan spends $1,794.60 (HB933_.HTM.txt) per month on food. [CHUNK_5] Based on this, the bill assumes this family would pay over $800 (HB933_.HTM.txt) a year in state taxes on those groceries. [CHUNK_5]",
  "agency_impact": "The department of business, economic development, and tourism is required to conduct an economic cost-benefit analysis on the general excise tax reductions for calendar year 2026. [CHUNK_22] This department shall submit a report of its findings from the analysis, including any recommendations and proposed legislation, to the legislature before the regular session of 2027. [CHUNK_23] The Department of Taxation will be impacted by the need to implement and administer a new reduced tax rate for specific goods. [CHUNK_11]",
  "economic_impact": "Lowering the tax rate on groceries and nonprescription drugs will have an immediate positive impact on Hawaii's cost of living by lowering the cost of these necessary items. [CHUNK_8] The legislature finds that taxing the sale of groceries is generally considered regressive and disproportionately hurts working families because they spend a higher percentage of their income on food. [CHUNK_3] A 2021 study by the University of Hawaii at Manoa stated that forty-eight per cent of Hawaii families with children are experiencing food insecurity. [CHUNK_2]",
  "policy_impact": "This Act amends Chapter 237, Hawaii Revised Statutes, by adding two new sections to establish a reduced general excise tax rate for eligible groceries and nonprescription drugs. [CHUNK_10] The tax rate will be one-half per cent less than the rate that would have applied pursuant to section 237-13. [CHUNK_12] This policy recognizes that certain items should have a lower tax burden, similar to the existing general exemption for amounts received by certain entities for selling prescription drugs. [CHUNK_7]",
  "revenue_sources": "The bill does not identify any new revenue sources to support the program or offset the tax reduction. [CHUNK_0] The reduction in the general excise tax will result in a decrease in revenue for the State's general fund. [CHUNK_8] No grants, fees, or other revenue streams are mentioned in the provided text. [CHUNK_0]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "Beginning January 1, 2026, the State will collect a tax equivalent to one-half per cent less than the standard rate on the sale of eligible groceries. [CHUNK_11] A tax equivalent to one-half per cent less than the standard rate will also be collected on the sale of nonprescription drugs, also beginning January 1, 2026. [CHUNK_17] This will result in a recurring loss of general fund revenue for the foreseeable future. [CHUNK_11] The exact fiscal impact is undetermined, but the bill provides an example from the United States Department of Agriculture, where a Hawaii family on a thrifty food plan spends $1,794.60 (HB933_.HTM.txt) per month on food. [CHUNK_5] This family would pay over $800 (HB933_.HTM.txt) a year in state taxes on those groceries, indicating the potential scale of the tax reduction's impact on an individual basis. [CHUNK_5] Even with the refundable food/excise tax credit, a family would likely get back less than one-half of those state taxes paid on groceries. [CHUNK_6] The department of business, economic development, and tourism is required to conduct an economic cost-benefit analysis on the general excise tax reductions for calendar year 2026. [CHUNK_22] A report with findings and recommendations is to be submitted to the legislature prior to the convening of the regular session of 2027. [CHUNK_23] This report should provide a clearer picture of the long-term fiscal implications. [CHUNK_23] The Act itself is scheduled to take effect on July 1, 2025. [CHUNK_24]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "This measure will reduce the State's operating revenue. [CHUNK_8] Beginning January 1, 2026, there shall be assessed and collected a tax equivalent to one-half per cent less than the rate that would have applied on the gross proceeds from the sale of eligible groceries and nonprescription drugs. [CHUNK_11] This reduction in the general excise tax rate will decrease tax collections from these sales. [CHUNK_25]",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The provided legislative documents do not mention any capital expenditures. [CHUNK_0] There are no anticipated investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure associated with this measure. [CHUNK_0] Therefore, there is no expected capital expenditure impact. [CHUNK_0]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The fiscal implications are expected to be ongoing as the bill does not include a sunset clause for the tax reduction. [CHUNK_11] The reduced tax rate on eligible groceries and nonprescription drugs will continue indefinitely, resulting in a permanent reduction of general fund revenues. [CHUNK_17] The long-term fiscal impact will depend on the volume of sales of these specific goods in the state. [CHUNK_12]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "No previous fiscal note was provided for comparison. [CHUNK_0]"
}

chunk_details.chunk_text: HB933 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 933 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 STATE OF HAWAII A BILL FOR AN ACT relating to general excise tax reductions . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: SECTION 1. The legislature finds that the cost of living in Hawaii is extremely

finds that the cost of living in Hawaii is extremely high and many residents are struggling to pay for food, medication, housing, and other necessities. Many Hawaii residents, including vulnerable populations, suffer from food insecurity. A 2021 study by the University of Hawaii at Manoa stated that forty-eight per cent

University of Hawaii at Manoa stated that forty-eight per cent of Hawaii families with children are experiencing food insecurity. A 2021 Cornell study indicated that even the slightest increase in tax rate correlated to an increased likelihood of food insecurity. The legislature further finds that only thirteen states tax most

The legislature further finds that only thirteen states tax most foods purchased for consumption at home from the state sales tax. Six of the states that tax groceries do so at a reduced rate. Taxing the sale of groceries is generally considered regressive and disproportionately hurts working families because they

generally considered regressive and disproportionately hurts working families because they spend a higher percentage of their income on food. Hawaii's general excise tax on groceries negatively affects not only the amount of food that Hawaii families can afford, but also the quality and diversity of their food choices. According to

the quality and diversity of their food choices. According to the United States Department of Agriculture, a Hawaii family on a thrifty food plan spends $1,794.60 per month on food. This family would pay over $800 a year in state taxes on those groceries. The thrifty food plan represents those

taxes on those groceries. The thrifty food plan represents those on a limited budget. Even if this family is eligible for a refundable food/excise tax credit, the family would likely get back less than one-half of those state taxes paid on groceries. The legislature has already recognized that certain items

on groceries. The legislature has already recognized that certain items should be exempt from the general excise tax, as evidenced by the existing general exemption for amounts received by certain entities for selling prescription drugs. Lowering the tax rate on groceries and nonprescription drugs will have an immediate positive impact

groceries and nonprescription drugs will have an immediate positive impact on Hawaii's cost of living by lowering the cost of these necessary items. Accordingly, the purpose of this Act is to: (1) Establish a reduction in the general excise tax rate on gross proceeds or income from the sale of

rate on gross proceeds or income from the sale of groceries that are eligible for purchase under the supplemental nutrition assistance program or special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children and from the sale of nonprescription drugs; and (2) Require the department of business, economic development and tourism

(2) Require the department of business, economic development and tourism to conduct an economic cost-benefit analysis on the general excise reductions and submit a report to the legislature. SECTION 2. Chapter 237, Hawaii Revised Statutes, is amended by adding two new sections to be appropriately designated and to read as

new sections to be appropriately designated and to read as follows: " § 237- Reduced rate; eligible groceries. (a) Notwithstanding section 237-13 to the contrary, beginning January 1, 2026, there is hereby levied and shall be assessed and collected a tax equivalent to one-half per cent less than the rate

tax equivalent to one-half per cent less than the rate that would have applied pursuant to section 237-13 of the gross proceeds or income received from the sale of all groceries eligible for purchase under the supplemental nutrition assistance program and special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children

and special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children within the State, regardless of the means of purchase and the eligibility of the purchaser for supplemental nutrition assistance program or special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children benefits. (b) For the purposes of this section: "Food" or

benefits. (b) For the purposes of this section: "Food" or "food product" means substances, whether in liquid, concentrated, solid, frozen, dried, or dehydrated form, that are sold for ingestion or chewing by humans and are consumed for their taste or nutritional value. "Groceries" means any food or food product for

nutritional value. "Groceries" means any food or food product for home consumption. "Groceries" may be further defined by the department by rule through the enumeration of items in rules or tax informational release; provided that the department shall consult with the federal Food and Nutrition Service of the United States

the federal Food and Nutrition Service of the United States Department of Agriculture in further defining the term "groceries" for purposes of the supplemental nutrition assistance program and special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children. §237- Reduced rate; nonprescription drugs. (a) Notwithstanding section 237-13 to the contrary, beginning

nonprescription drugs. (a) Notwithstanding section 237-13 to the contrary, beginning January 1, 2026, there is hereby levied and shall be assessed and collected a tax equivalent to one-half per cent less than the rate that would have applied pursuant to section 237-13 of the gross proceeds or income received from

section 237-13 of the gross proceeds or income received from the sale of nonprescription drugs. (b) For the purposes of this section: "Drug" means: (1) Articles recognized in the official United States Pharmacopoeia, official United States Pharmacopoeia Dispensing Information, official Homeopathic Pharmacopoeia of the United States, or official National Formulary,

Homeopathic Pharmacopoeia of the United States, or official National Formulary, or any supplement to any of these publications; (2) Articles intended for use in the diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease in humans; (3) Articles, other than food or clothing, intended to affect the structure or any function

or clothing, intended to affect the structure or any function of the body of humans; or (4) Articles intended for use as a component of any article specified in paragraph (1), (2), or (3); provided that the term "drug" does not include devices or their components, parts or accessories, cosmetics,

not include devices or their components, parts or accessories, cosmetics, or liquor as defined in section 281-1. "Nonprescription drug" means any packaged, bottled, or nonbulk chemical, drug, or medicine that may be lawfully sold without a practitioner's order. " SECTION 3. (a) By December 1, 2026, the department of business,

3. (a) By December 1, 2026, the department of business, economic development, and tourism shall conduct an economic cost-benefit analysis on the general excise tax reductions for calendar year 2026 as provided in section 2 of this Act. (b) The department of business, economic development, and tourism shall submit a

department of business, economic development, and tourism shall submit a report of its findings from the economic cost-benefit analysis, including any recommendations and proposed legislation, to the legislature no later than twenty days prior to the convening of the regular session of 2027. SECTION 4. New statutory material is underscored.

session of 2027. SECTION 4. New statutory material is underscored. SECTION 5. This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2025. INTRODUCED BY: _____________________________ Report Title: General Excise Tax; Rate Reduction; SNAP; WIC; Groceries; Nonprescription Drugs; DBEDT Description: Reduces the general excise tax rate on the gross proceeds or income

general excise tax rate on the gross proceeds or income from the sale of groceries that are eligible under the supplemental nutrition assistance program (SNAP) or special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children (WIC), regardless of the means of purchase and the program eligibility of the purchaser. Reduces

of purchase and the program eligibility of the purchaser. Reduces the general excise tax rate on the gross proceeds or income from the sale of nonprescription drugs. Requires DBEDT to conduct an economic cost-benefit analysis on the GET reductions. The summary description of legislation appearing on this page is for
summary description of legislation appearing on this page is for informational purposes only and is not legislation or evidence of legislative intent.

HB933.chunk_text: HB933 HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES H.B. NO. 933 THIRTY-THIRD LEGISLATURE, 2025 STATE OF HAWAII A BILL FOR AN ACT relating to general excise tax reductions . BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF HAWAII: SECTION 1. The legislature finds that the cost of living in Hawaii is extremely

finds that the cost of living in Hawaii is extremely high and many residents are struggling to pay for food, medication, housing, and other necessities. Many Hawaii residents, including vulnerable populations, suffer from food insecurity. A 2021 study by the University of Hawaii at Manoa stated that forty-eight per cent

University of Hawaii at Manoa stated that forty-eight per cent of Hawaii families with children are experiencing food insecurity. A 2021 Cornell study indicated that even the slightest increase in tax rate correlated to an increased likelihood of food insecurity. The legislature further finds that only thirteen states tax most

The legislature further finds that only thirteen states tax most foods purchased for consumption at home from the state sales tax. Six of the states that tax groceries do so at a reduced rate. Taxing the sale of groceries is generally considered regressive and disproportionately hurts working families because they

generally considered regressive and disproportionately hurts working families because they spend a higher percentage of their income on food. Hawaii's general excise tax on groceries negatively affects not only the amount of food that Hawaii families can afford, but also the quality and diversity of their food choices. According to

the quality and diversity of their food choices. According to the United States Department of Agriculture, a Hawaii family on a thrifty food plan spends $1,794.60 per month on food. This family would pay over $800 a year in state taxes on those groceries. The thrifty food plan represents those

taxes on those groceries. The thrifty food plan represents those on a limited budget. Even if this family is eligible for a refundable food/excise tax credit, the family would likely get back less than one-half of those state taxes paid on groceries. The legislature has already recognized that certain items

on groceries. The legislature has already recognized that certain items should be exempt from the general excise tax, as evidenced by the existing general exemption for amounts received by certain entities for selling prescription drugs. Lowering the tax rate on groceries and nonprescription drugs will have an immediate positive impact

groceries and nonprescription drugs will have an immediate positive impact on Hawaii's cost of living by lowering the cost of these necessary items. Accordingly, the purpose of this Act is to: (1) Establish a reduction in the general excise tax rate on gross proceeds or income from the sale of

rate on gross proceeds or income from the sale of groceries that are eligible for purchase under the supplemental nutrition assistance program or special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children and from the sale of nonprescription drugs; and (2) Require the department of business, economic development and tourism

(2) Require the department of business, economic development and tourism to conduct an economic cost-benefit analysis on the general excise reductions and submit a report to the legislature. SECTION 2. Chapter 237, Hawaii Revised Statutes, is amended by adding two new sections to be appropriately designated and to read as

new sections to be appropriately designated and to read as follows: " § 237- Reduced rate; eligible groceries. (a) Notwithstanding section 237-13 to the contrary, beginning January 1, 2026, there is hereby levied and shall be assessed and collected a tax equivalent to one-half per cent less than the rate

tax equivalent to one-half per cent less than the rate that would have applied pursuant to section 237-13 of the gross proceeds or income received from the sale of all groceries eligible for purchase under the supplemental nutrition assistance program and special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children

and special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children within the State, regardless of the means of purchase and the eligibility of the purchaser for supplemental nutrition assistance program or special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children benefits. (b) For the purposes of this section: "Food" or

benefits. (b) For the purposes of this section: "Food" or "food product" means substances, whether in liquid, concentrated, solid, frozen, dried, or dehydrated form, that are sold for ingestion or chewing by humans and are consumed for their taste or nutritional value. "Groceries" means any food or food product for

nutritional value. "Groceries" means any food or food product for home consumption. "Groceries" may be further defined by the department by rule through the enumeration of items in rules or tax informational release; provided that the department shall consult with the federal Food and Nutrition Service of the United States

the federal Food and Nutrition Service of the United States Department of Agriculture in further defining the term "groceries" for purposes of the supplemental nutrition assistance program and special supplemental nutrition program for women, infants, and children. §237- Reduced rate; nonprescription drugs. (a) Notwithstanding section 237-13 to the contrary, beginning

nonprescription drugs. (a) Notwithstanding section 237-13 to the contrary, beginning January 1, 2026, there is hereby levied and shall be assessed and collected a tax equivalent to one-half per cent less than the rate that would have applied pursuant to section 237-13 of the gross proceeds or income received from

section 237-13 of the gross proceeds or income received from the sale of nonprescription drugs. (b) For the purposes of this section: "Drug" means: (1) Articles recognized in the official United States Pharmacopoeia, official United States Pharmacopoeia Dispensing Information, official Homeopathic Pharmacopoeia of the United States, or official National Formulary,

Homeopathic Pharmacopoeia of the United States, or official National Formulary, or any supplement to any of these publications; (2) Articles intended for use in the diagnosis, cure, mitigation, treatment, or prevention of disease in humans; (3) Articles, other than food or clothing, intended to affect the structure or any function

or clothing, intended to affect the structure or any function of the body of humans; or (4) Articles intended for use as a component of any article specified in paragraph (1), (2), or (3); provided that the term "drug" does not include devices or their components, parts or accessories, cosmetics,

not include devices or their components, parts or accessories, cosmetics, or liquor as defined in section 281-1. "Nonprescription drug" means any packaged, bottled, or nonbulk chemical, drug, or medicine that may be lawfully sold without a practitioner's order. " SECTION 3. (a) By December 1, 2026, the department of business,

3. (a) By December 1, 2026, the department of business, economic development, and tourism shall conduct an economic cost-benefit analysis on the general excise tax reductions for calendar year 2026 as provided in section 2 of this Act. (b) The department of business, economic development, and tourism shall submit a

department of business, economic development, and tourism shall submit a report of its findings from the economic cost-benefit analysis, including any recommendations and proposed legislation, to the legislature no later than twenty days prior to the convening of the regular session of 2027. SECTION 4. New statutory material is underscored.

session of 2027. SECTION 4. New statutory material is underscored. SECTION 5. This Act shall take effect on July 1, 2025.
